li.a: WSO2 ESB Graphical Composition Editor - How To Guide
Support for Different WSO2 ESB Versions

body.p: With WSO2 Developer Studio 3.0.0, we introduce a new project type called ESB Config Project to save all the ESB related artifacts such as Proxy Services, Endpoints, Sequences, local Entries, API, Tasks, Templates and Synapse Configurations.
To create a ESB Config Project, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select ESB Config Project from Enterprise Service Bus category.
Give a name to the ESB Config Project and click Finish.
Now you will see a new project has been created in the workspace. If you browse inside the project, you will see a project structure as below.

All your endpoints will be saved in to the endpoints folder, sequences will be saved in sequences folder, local entries in to local-entries folder, proxy services in to proxy-services folder,APIs in to api folder, tasks in to tasks folder and templates in to template folder.
body.h2: Support for Different WSO2 ESB Versions
body.p: Latest version of WSO2 ESB is 4.0.0. Still we have lot of people, who heavily use WSO2 ESB 3.0.1 as well. WSO2 ESB 4.0.0 introduces lot of new mediators such as
At the same time, lot of other mediators have been modified in order to support more user friendly functionalities.
WSO2 Developer Studio supports both ESB versions in the ESB editor. This support is enabled via a flag that you set in Eclipse Preference page.

To select the needed WSO2 ESB version, go to Window -> Preferences page. Select ESB category from Developer Studio section. Then you can select needed version as you wish. By default WSO2 ESB 4.0.0 version will be set.
Now when you create a sequence, you will see all the new and modified mediators will appear.
If you set back the version to 3.0.1, you will see those mediators will disappear.
If you want to apply the version change to already created ESB configuration, you have to reload the editor in order to preference modification to be effected in the editor.
To create a Sequence, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select Sequence from Enterprise Service Bus category.
There are two ways to create a Sequence.

If you select the first option and go forward, in the next wizard, give a name for the sequence and there's a field called Save Sequence In. This field is where you specify the ESB Config Project in which you want to save the sequence. If you have ESB Config Projects already in your workspace, you can click on the Browse button and select the ESB Config Project that already in the workspace.
If you do not have ESB Config Projects, you can create a new ESB Config Project by clicking on Create new ESB Project... button.

Inside Advanced Configuration section, you can specify On Error Sequence and Available Endpoints if you have sequences and endpoints defined in your workspace. Sequence configuration will be updated accordingly.

Once you click Finish, you will see a Sequence being created under src/main/synapse-configs/sequences folder and it is being opened in ESB Graphical Editor which is new graphical esb editor inbuilt with WSO2 Developer Studio.
You can see that the given Endpoint and Error Sequence information being added to the configuration.

If you want to open that sequence using ESB Tree Editorwhich is also inbuilt with WSO2 Developer Studio.Right click on the sequence file go toOpen With in the right click menu and select the ESB Editorin the Open With sub menu.

If you select Import Sequence from File System option, you can upload a Synapse Configuration file or any XML file which contains a sequence, from the file system. Once you set the file, it will display all the sequences that are available in the file.
You can select multiple sequences at once and once you click Finish, you will see that the selected sequences are being added to the project.
In the similar manner you create a sequence, you can create Endpoints as well. To create an Endpoint, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select Endpoint from Enterprise Service Bus category.
There are two ways to create an Endpoint.

If you select the first option and click Next, in the wizard page, give a name for the endpoint. There's a field called Save Endpoint In. This field is where you specify the ESB Config Project in which you want to save the endpoint. If you have ESB Config Projects already in your workspace, you can click on the Browse button and select the ESB Config Project that already in the workspace.
If you do not have ESB Config Projects, you can create a new ESB Config Project by clicking on Create new ESB Project... button.
There are several endpoint templates that are provided.

Advanced Configuration section will be filled according to the Endpoint Template that you select. For an example, if you select WSDL Endpoint, you need to fill information like WSDL URI, Service and Port.

Select the template and fill necessary information and click Finish. Now you will see the endpoint has been created under src/main/synapse-configs/endpoints and it will open with the ESB Graphical Editor.
If you want to open that endpoint using ESB Tree Editor.Right click on the endpoint file go toOpen With in the right click menu and select the ESB Editorin the Open With sub menu.

If you select Import Endpoint option, you can upload a Synapse Configuration file or any XML file which contains a endpoints, from the file system. Once you set the file, it will display all the endpoints that are available in the file.
You can select multiple endpoints at once and once you click Finish, you will see that the selected endpoints are being added to the project.

In the similar manner you did for sequences and endpoints, you can create Local Entries as well. To create an Local Entry, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select Local Entry from Enterprise Service Bus category.
There are two ways to create a Sequence.

If you select the first option and click Next, in the wizard page, give a name for the local-entry. There's a field called Save Local Entry In. This field is where you specify the ESB Config Project in which you want to save the local-entr. If you have ESB Config Projects already in your workspace, you can click on the Browse button and select the ESB Config Project that already in the workspace.
If you do not have ESB Config Projects, you can create a new ESB Config Project by clicking on Create new ESB Project... button.
There are several ways that you can create a local-entry.
Advanced Configuration section will be filled according to the Local-Entry Creation Type that you select. For an example, if you select In-Line Text Entry, you need to fill Value feild.

Select the template and fill necessary information, then click Finish. Now you will see the local entry has been created under src/main/synapse-configs/local-entries and it will open with the ESB Graphical Editor.
If you want to open that local entry using ESB Tree Editor.Right click on the local entry file go toOpen With in the right click menu and select the ESB Editorin the Open With sub menu.

If you select Import Local Entry option, you can upload any Synapse Configuration file or any XML file which contains a local-entries, from the file system. Once you set the file, it will display all the local-entries that are available in the file.
You can select multiple local-entries at once and once you click Finish, you will see that the selected local-entries are being added to the project.

In the similar manner you create a sequence and other artifacts, you can create Proxy Services as well. To create a Proxy Service, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select Proxy Service from Enterprise Service Bus category.
There are two ways to create a Proxy Service.

ol.li: Import Proxy Service from File System

body.p: If you select the first option and click Next, in the wizard page, give a name for the proxy service. There's a field called Save Proxy Service In. This field is where you specify the ESB Config Project in which you want to save the endpoint. If you have ESB Config Projects already in your workspace, you can click on the Browse button and select the ESB Config Project that already in the workspace.
If you do not have ESB Config Projects, you can create a new ESB Config Project by clicking on Create new ESB Project... button.
There are several proxy service templates that are provided.

Advanced Configuration section will be filled according to the Proxy Service Template that you select. For an example, if you select WSDL Based Proxy Service, you need to fill information like WSDL URI, WSDL Service and WSDL Port.

Select the template and fill necessary information and click Finish. Now you will see the proxy service has been created under src/main/synapse-configs/proxy-services and it will open with the ESB Graphical Editor.
If you want to open that proxy service using ESB Tree Editor.Right click on the local entry file go toOpen With in the right click menu and select the ESB Editorin the Open With sub menu.

If you select Import Proxy Service option, you can upload a Synapse Configuration file or any XML file which contains a proxy services, from the file system. Once you set the file, it will display all the proxy services that are available in the file.
You can select multiple proxy services at once, and once you click Finish, you will see that the selected proxy services are being added to the project.

In the similar manner you create a sequence and other artifacts, you can create REST API as well. To create a API, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select API from Enterprise Service Bus category.
There are two ways to create a API.

If you select the first option and click Next, in the wizard page, give a name for the API and spefify the context,Host name and Port There's a field called Save API In. This field is where you specify the ESB Config Project in which you want to save the API. If you have ESB Config Projects already in your workspace, you can click on the Browse button and select the ESB Config Project that already in the workspace.
If you do not have ESB Config Projects, you can create a new ESB Config Project by clicking on Create new ESB Project... button.
After fill necessary infortmation and click Finish. Now you will see the API has been created under src/main/synapse-configs/api and it will open with the ESB Graphical Editor.
If you want to open that API using ESB Tree Editor.Right click on the local entry file go toOpen With in the right click menu and select the ESB Editorin the Open With sub menu.

If you select Import API option, you can upload a Synapse Configuration file or any XML file which contains a API, from the file system. Once you set the file, it will display all the APIs that are available in the file.
You can select multiple APIs at once, and once you click Finish, you will see that the selected APIs are being added to the project.

In the similar manner you create a sequence and other artifacts, you can create Scheduled Tasks as well. To create a Tasks, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select Scheduled Tasks from Enterprise Service Bus category.
There are two ways to create a Scheduled Task.

If you select the first option and click Next, in the wizard page, give a name for the Task and spefify the Group and Implimentation. There's a field called Save Tasks In.This field is where you specify the ESB Config Project in which you want to save the Tasks. If you have ESB Config Projects already in your workspace, you can click on the Browse button and select the ESB Config Project that already in the workspace.
If you do not have ESB Config Projects, you can create a new ESB Config Project by clicking on Create new ESB Project... button.
After fill necessary infortmation and click Finish. Now you will see the Task has been created under src/main/synapse-configs/tasks and it will open with the ESB Graphical Editor.
If you want to open that task using ESB Tree Editor.Right click on the local entry file go toOpen With in the right click menu and select the ESB Editorin the Open With sub menu.

If you select Import Tasks option, you can upload a Synapse Configuration file or any XML file which contains a Task, from the file system. Once you set the file, it will display all the Tasks that are available in the file.
You can select multiple Tasks at once, and once you click Finish, you will see that the selected Tasks are being added to the project.

In the similar manner you create a proxy services and other artifacts, you can create Templates as well. To create a Template, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select Template from Enterprise Service Bus category.
There are two ways to create a Templates.

If you select the first option and click Next, in the wizard page, give a name for the proxy service. There's a field called Save Proxy Service In. This field is where you specify the ESB Config Project in which you want to save the endpoint. If you have ESB Config Projects already in your workspace, you can click on the Browse button and select the ESB Config Project that already in the workspace.
If you do not have ESB Config Projects, you can create a new ESB Config Project by clicking on Create new ESB Project... button.
There are several templates that are provided.

Advanced Configuration section will be filled according to the Template that you select. For an example, if you select WSDL Endpoint Template, you need to fill information like WSDL URI, WSDL Service and WSDL Port.

Select the template and fill necessary information and click Finish. Now you will see the template has been created under src/main/synapse-configs/templates and it will open with the ESB Graphical Editor.
If you want to open that proxy service using ESB Tree Editor.Right click on the template file go toOpen With in the right click menu and select the ESB Editorin the Open With sub menu.

If you select Import template option, you can upload a Synapse Configuration file or any XML file which contains a templates, from the file system. Once you set the file, it will display all the templates that are available in the file.
You can select multiple templates at once, and once you click Finish, you will see that the selected templates are being added to the project.

In the similar manner you create a sequence and other artifacts, you can create Synapse Configurations as well. To create a Synapse Configuration, open WSO2 Developer Studio Dashboard and select Synapse Configuration from Enterprise Service Bus category.
There are three ways to create a Synapse Configuration.

ol.li: Import Synapse Configuration From File System

body.p: If you select the first option you need to give a name for the synapse configuration. There's a field called Save Synapse Configuration In. This field is where you specify the ESB Config Project in which you want to save the synapse configuration. If you have ESB Config Projects already in your workspace, you can click on the Browse button and select the ESB Config Project that already in the workspace.
If you do not have ESB Config Projects, you can create a new ESB Config Project by clicking on Create new ESB Project... button.
Once you click Finish, you will see a simple synapse configuration has been created under src/main/synapse-config folder.
If you select Create New Synapse Configuration With Template option, fill the necessary fields as you did for the first option, and click Finish.
Now you will see new Synapse Configuration file has been create with a template which has main and fault sequences.
With the third option, you can upload an already existing Synapse Configuration file and create seperate ESB Artifacts.

Once you click Finish, you will see that all the endpoints defined in the Synapse Configuration saved inside src/main/synapse-config/endpoints folder and all proxy services saved inside src/main/synapse-config/proxy-services etc.

Content assist to Synapse Configuration are now supported with WSO2 Developer Studio. If you have a Synapse Configuration or Proxy Service or Sequence, you have the content assist support if you go to the source view.
For example, suppose you have a simple Synapase Configuration and you go to the source view.
I removed the end tag and press cntrl + space at the end. Now you can see, it suggests all the possible options that are available at that point.
You can get the similar behavior at source view of any of the ESB configuration files such as proxy services, endpoints, sequences, local entries.

In order to create a Smooks Configuration Artifact, first you need to create a Registry Resource. Go through how to create a Registry Resource document. When creating the Registry Resource, select From Existing Template option and select the template as Smooks Configuration.
Now you will see smooks-configuration file has been created and it will be open in the embedded JBoss Smooks editor.
You can find more information regarding how to map data using smooks configuration from here.
Create the smooks configuration and save the file.
To run the created smooks-configuration, you will need to add libraries from smooks framework. To add these libraries select the Registry Resources project and go to Project -> Properties.
Select Java Build Path and go to Libraries tab.
Click on Add Library button and you will see Add Library page which has WSO2 Classpath Libraries entry at the bottom.

Select WSO2 Classpath Libraries and click Next. Now you will see a multi-tab page which includes most of the third party libraries that will be needed for your SOA development. To add smooks related libraries, go to Smooks tab.
Select all the libraries by clicking Select All button and click Finish.
Now you will see, all the smooks related libraries are added to project classpath.
Now you can run smooks configuration file by right click on the file and select Run As -> Smooks Run Configuration after doing the mapping you need.
If your Smooks Configuration is correct, it will show the results according to the Input Model and the Output Model that you have specified in the console.

You can add this newly created smooks configuration artifact in to ESB Tools via a Proxy Service or a Sequence. To do so, let's create a Proxy Service as mentioned Proxy Service section. Then you can see there is a selection called Anonymous under InSequance drop down.If it is not there click on InsSquance and set Anonymous from its properties.
Next right click on Anonymous and then select New Child -> Advanced -> Smooks from the menu.
Once you double click on the Smooks mediator, you will see that the Properties view get focused. From the Properties view, click on the button at the right hand corner of Configuration Key field.
Once you click on the button, it will open the Resource Key Editor dialog which you can specify from where you should select the resource file.
Select Workspace option since we have the created Smooks Configuration in our workspace. Browse for the Smooks Configuration file that we have created and click OK.
Now you have successfully refer the created Smooks Configuration within your proxy service.
Once you create all the ESB components such as sequences, proxy services, endpoints, local-entries, you can create a Carbon Application Project to group them and create a Carbon Application Archive.
You can select individual components as well.
